odeProperty.value: The World of TV: Creating a Talk Show
Learning Object based on TBLT and Nunan's framework to practice passive voice in a contextualized way.
Desinged by Jorge Enrique Muñoz Oyola

odeNavStructure.pageName: The World of TV: Creating a Talk Show

odeNavStructureProperty.value: The World of TV: Creating a Talk Show
The World of TV: Creating a Talk Show

odeComponent.htmlView:
Greetings! I'm George and I will guide you to carry out a project, which is based on the Task-Based Language Teaching (TBLT) approach and David Nunan's frawork. Specifically, you will work in groups and do a six-stage project: a Talk Show where you interview famous people and talk about amazing stories. This learning object has been specially designed for people who have an intermediate English level and study English in online or hybrid environments.

I hope you enjoy the tasks and improve your communicative competences!
odeComponent.jsonProperties:
{"ideviceId":"20251102233308HDWTDE","textInfoDurationInput":"","textInfoDurationTextInput":"Duración:","textInfoParticipantsInput":"","textInfoParticipantsTextInput":"Grouping:","textTextarea":"

   

\n

Greetings! I'm George and I will guide you to carry out a project, which is based on the Task-Based Language Teaching (TBLT) approach and David Nunan's frawork. Specifically, you will work in groups and do a six-stage project: a Talk Show where you interview famous people and talk about amazing stories. This learning object has been specially designed for people who have an intermediate English level and study English in online or hybrid environments.

\n

I hope you enjoy the tasks and improve your communicative competences!

","textFeedbackInput":"Mostrar retroalimentación","textFeedbackTextarea":""}

odeComponent.htmlView:
Competencias – Descriptores MCER

Este nivel desarrolla habilidades lingüísticas básicas y lleva a los estudiantes del nivel A2 al nivel B1. Al finalizar el Objeto de Aprendizaje los estudiantes adquieren las siguientes competencias:

  • Hablar de los gustos personales. 
  • Hablar sobre eventos del pasado. 
  • Expresar sentimientos, sensaciones, experiencias y logros personales. 
  • Expresar opiniones personales.
odeComponent.jsonProperties:
{"ideviceId":"20251102233308RTZGHN","textInfoDurationInput":"","textInfoDurationTextInput":"Duración:","textInfoParticipantsInput":"","textInfoParticipantsTextInput":"Grouping:","textTextarea":"

  • Hablar sobre eventos del pasado. 
  • Expresar sentimientos, sensaciones, experiencias y logros personales. 
  • Expresar opiniones personales.

Watch the video to get familiar with vocabulary and expressions about TV shows. Then, answer the questions.

\n


\n


","questionsData":[{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

1. A(n) __________ is a period when a set of programs, plays, or musical events are broadcast or performed.

","answers":[[false,"episode"],[true,"season"],[false,"show"]]},{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

2. A __________ is a program or film that has already been shown before on television.

","answers":[[false,"season premiere"],[false,"season finale"],[true,"rerun"]]},{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

3. If your computer doesn’t have space, you can watch a TV show by __________.

","answers":[[false,"downloading"],[true,"streaming"],[false,"channel surfing"]]},{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

4. If someone asks “What’s on?”, the person wants to know:

","answers":[[true,"What you are watching on TV."],[false,"What you are doing at home."],[false,"What you are studying in your room."]]},{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

5. If a TV show goes off air, it means that:

","answers":[[false,"It is on air."],[false,"It is interesting."],[true,"It is over."]]}],"passRate":5,"addBtnAnswers":true,"eXeIdeviceTextAfter":"","showSlider":false}

Based on the conversation, choose the correct answer:

\n

1. What was the girls’ favorite childhood TV show?

","answers":[[false,"Fred Savage"],[true,"Wonder Years"],[false,"Winnie"]]},{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

2. When the girl says she had “a huge mad crush” on the TV character, she means that:

","answers":[[false,"She hated the main character"],[false,"She liked his childhood"],[true,"She was in love"]]},{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

3. How did she feel when she saw the same character after some years?

","answers":[[false,"In love"],[true,"Disappointed"],[false,"Depressed"]]},{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

4. What did the man have to do to watch TV as a child?

","answers":[[false,"Cook"],[true,"Do it secretly"],[false,"Go to a teenager’s house"]]},{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

5. Why did he learn about computers?

","answers":[[true,"He was banned from watching TV"],[false,"Both his brother and sister had a computer"],[false,"He played a Simpsons game"]]}],"passRate":5,"addBtnAnswers":true,"eXeIdeviceTextAfter":"","showSlider":false}

Has fallado la prueba","msgTrueFalseHelp":"Di si la afirmación es verdadera o falsa","msgDropdownHelp":"Elige la respuesta correcta entre las opciones propuestas","msgFillHelp":"Rellena los espacios en blanco con la palabra apropiada","msgSingleSelectionHelp":"Opción múltiple con solo una respuesta correcta","msgMultipleSelectionHelp":"Opción múltiple con varias respuestas correctas","msgPlayStart":"Pulse aquí para empezar","msgTrue":"Verdadero","msgFalse":"Falso","msgNext":"Siguiente","msgPrevious":"Anterior"},"id":"20251102220210508LOZ","questionsRandom":false,"percentageQuestions":"100","time":"0","eXeFormInstructions":"

Watch the video and answer the questions.

\n


","questionsData":[{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

1. What was the primary reason Jerry was late for work on the day he saw the zebra?

","answers":[[true,"An unusual traffic jam was caused by an escaped zoo animal"],[false,"He was delayed by normal, heavy rush hour traffic"],[false,"He was involved in a minor car accident with another vehicle"],[false,"He stopped to help zookeepers recapture the escaped animals"]]},{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

2. Why was Jerry temporarily arrested by a policeman the previous day?

","answers":[[false,"He refused to get out of his car when pulled over"],[false,"He matched the description of a suspect who robbed a bank"],[true,"The police believed his car was used in a gas station robbery"],[false,"He was caught speeding in a stolen vehicle"]]},{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

3. What happened to Jerry's car on Monday morning?

","answers":[[false,"It was used by robbers and crashed during a police chase"],[true,"It was stolen but was recovered by the police later the same day"],[false,"It was impounded by the police as evidence in a crime"],[false,"It broke down, forcing him to take his wife's car to work"]]},{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

4. How did the zoo animals accidentally get released from their cages?

","answers":[[false,"The gas station robbers created a diversion at the zoo"],[false,"A zookeeper intentionally set them free as a prank"],[true,"An animal feeder suffered a medical emergency while opening the cages."],[false,"The animals broke through a faulty lock on their enclosure"]]},{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"","answers":[]},{"activityType":"selection","selectionType":"single","baseText":"

5. What ultimately caused Carlos to believe Jerry's series of unbelievable stories?

","answers":[[false,"He felt guilty for doubting Jerry and decided to trust him anyway"],[false,"Jerry's wife called Carlos to verify the story about the stolen car"],[false,"Jerry provided a written report from the police department"],[true,"He watched a news broadcast that confirmed the key events"]]}],"passRate":5,"addBtnAnswers":true,"eXeIdeviceTextAfter":"","showSlider":false}

odeComponent.htmlView:
1. Remember an amazing story that has happed to you.

2. Prepare a 3-minute presentation to talk about it. 

3. Be ready to socialize your story with your classmates.

odeComponent.htmlView:
1. Listen to a teacher explain the use of passive voice and take notes for future reference.


2. Watch a Grammar Gameshow to practice passive voice and take notes for future reference.


3. Click on the following links and practice the use of passive voice.

https://learnenglish.britishcouncil.org/grammar/english-grammar-reference/active-passive-voice

https://learnenglish.britishcouncil.org/grammar/b1-b2-grammar/passives

You can activate the subtitles if you find it difficult to understand.

odeComponent.htmlView:
Harry Potter was written by J.K Rowling. Watch this interview about "Fantastic Beasts" and pay attention to the way she expresses some ideas in passive voice.


Activate subtitles to understand the interview better.
odeComponent.jsonProperties:
{"ideviceId":"20251102233308RILHAZ","textInfoDurationInput":"","textInfoDurationTextInput":"Duración:","textInfoParticipantsInput":"","textInfoParticipantsTextInput":"Grouping:","textTextarea":"

Harry Potter was written by J.K Rowling. Watch this interview about \"Fantastic Beasts\" and pay attention to the way she expresses some ideas in passive voice.

\n


","textFeedbackInput":"Mostrar retroalimentación","textFeedbackTextarea":"

Activate subtitles to understand the interview better.

"}

{"ideviceId":"20251102233308IHDVXK","eXeFormInstructions":"

Watch the video and fill in the missing words.

","questionsData":[{"activityType":"fill","baseText":"

Step 1: Give your narrator information about the project

In order to contact your narrator, you can mail a biography form or do an initial interview . It is also important that you treat the narrator with respect .

Step 2: Gather information about your narrator

You can ask the narrator to share any artifacts relevant to the interview, so collect memory clues .

Step 3: Review what you know about the narrator

You should write a list of topics that you think you will need to learn more about and send the narrator a list of questions before the interview.

Step 4: Learn where to go for information

You should familiarize yourself with how to do research using different sources such as databases , reference tools, search engines , local libraries, historical societies and websites.

Step 5: Begin your research

Once you have identified the topics and the best sources for information, make sure you research the narrators story and keep your notes organized .

","capitalization":"false","strict":"false"}],"formPreview":"","dropdownPassRate":"50","checkAddBtnAnswers":true,"userTranslations":{"langTrueFalseHelp":"Select whether the statement is true or false","langDropdownHelp":"Choose the correct answer among the options proposed","langSingleSelectionHelp":"Multiple choice with only one correct answer","langMultipleSelectionHelp":"Multiple choice with multiple corrects answers","langFillHelp":"Fill in the blanks with the appropriate word"}}

{"ideviceId":"20251102233308ZHRTTN","eXeFormInstructions":"

Watch the second part of the video and fill in the missing words.

","questionsData":[{"activityType":"fill","baseText":"

Step 1: Write Interview Questions

As you start brainstorming, make sure you ask brief questions. The idea is that the narrator should do most of the talking, so ask questions that require more than a  one-word answer. In addition, ask neutral questions; that is, the narrator should tell his or her story withoutbeinginfluenced by you.

In addition, make sure you get specific details , for instance, names , dates and places . Once you have a long list of questions, organize them into logical categories . This will help you narrowdown your list.

Step 2: Send the questions to your narrator

Sending your interview to the narrator allows him or her to think about the questions aheadoftime and pullout any artifacts or photos that might be relevant to the interview.

Step 3: Assemble your questions into a script

Any interview is basically broken into three separate parts: the beginning , the middle and the end . The first one is related to the narrator's background. You may use memory clues to ask for a description of the person's character or personality traits .

The second section is where you ask most the questions following the script . It is also where you ask the deeper questions to really getat the narrator's story. Don't forget to ask your questions in chronological order.

Finally, the last part wil be mostly thought questions which ask the narrator to reflecton experiences and things that have happened in their lifetime .

Remember that the purpose of the interview is not to ask for known information; conversely, the purpose is to add this person's firsthandaccounts to our historical records .

","capitalization":"false","strict":"false"}],"formPreview":"","dropdownPassRate":"50","checkAddBtnAnswers":true,"userTranslations":{"langTrueFalseHelp":"Select whether the statement is true or false","langDropdownHelp":"Choose the correct answer among the options proposed","langSingleSelectionHelp":"Multiple choice with only one correct answer","langMultipleSelectionHelp":"Multiple choice with multiple corrects answers","langFillHelp":"Fill in the blanks with the appropriate word"}}

{"ideviceId":"20251102233308NUZUDM","eXeFormInstructions":"

Watch the third part of the video and fill in the gaps.

","questionsData":[{"activityType":"fill","baseText":"

Step 1: Set-up the interview environment

Make sure the interview space is well-lit and be free from distracting noises . Interviews work best when it is the two of but it is acceptable to have a third person operating the recording equipment . You may ask the narrator to repeat questions but some people find this too awkward . 

Step 2: Respect the narrator

Be sure to go the extra mile to show respect for your narrator. Common courtesies include being on time and dressing appropriately. So, an outfit that works for a school dance might not be right for interviewing someone who wears conservative attire .

Don't be afraid of silence or moments where the narrator gets emotional; people can get choked up as they remember memories .

Step 3: Follow a structured, well researched format

Begin with simple questions and set the narrator at ease for the interview. Remember it is important to establish a certain level of trust with your narrator.

The middle section is where you get into the whole purpose of the interview, so do not follow the script exactly but ask follow-up questions. Take advantage of this as an opportunity to learn more and talk further . Additionally, avoid off the record information because the narrator may feel uncomfortable.

Step 4: Wrap-up after the interview

When the interview is over , review your notes and make sure you have correct spellings of names and places mentioned during the interview. The last task is to make the narrator sign the legal release form.

Watch this video to learn some tips for presenting shows on TV. Put them into practice when creating your Talk Show.

You may enable the subtitles to better understand the information given.

1. Take notes of the most relevant aspects from the previous videos.

2. Divide the roles into hosts (interviewers) and guests (interviewees) to create your talk show.

3. Decide what famous people you want to act out.

4. Make sure the Talk Show includes passive voice and the three sections explained above: beginning, middle and end.

5. Prepare and role play the interview.

6. Check the evaluation rubric to meet the requirements (Assessment).
